Award.AwardTitle: Tracking Sea-level Source Contributions: A Hemispheric Approach to High Resolution Sea-level Variation Over the Last Two Millennia
Award.AbstractNarration:
Accurate estimates of sea-level rise in the pre-satellite era are needed to provide appropriate context for 21st century projections and to validate geophysical and climate models. Exploring geographic trends in sea level are critical for this because sea-level changes are not globally uniform and involve isostatic deformation of the solid Earth along with gravitational and rotational changes driven by the exchange of mass between oceans and ice sheets. The aim of the study is to produce high-resolution reconstructions of sea-level change for the past two millennia along the Atlantic coasts of South Africa and Argentina. Relative sea levels along these coastlines are influenced by melting of both the Greenland and Western Antarctic Ice Sheets (GIS and WAIS). Four hypothetical hypotheses related to the timing and magnitude of sea-level changes: (1) The magnitude of sea-level rise since AD ~1850 is greater in Argentina and South Africa than New England which may indicate more ice-melt contribution from the GIS; (2) The magnitude of the deceleration in relative sea-level rise associated with the Little Ice Age (c. AD 1500-1850) is greater in New England then in South Africa or Argentina; (3) The magnitude of relative sea-level rise during the Medieval Climate Anomaly (c. AD 1000-1500) increased more in New England then in South Africa and Argentina; and (4) The magnitude of relative sea-level change prior to AD 1000 was slower than that since AD 1000 to present. New microfossil-based transfer functions approach to sea-level reconstruction in salt-marsh sediments will be used ot develop a high-resolution record. This approach combined with a suite of complementary dating methods affords the ability to precisely constrain the chronology (decadal to centennial age resolution) of subtle changes in sea level. In this project, high-resolution relative sea-level reconstructions spanning the past 2000 years will be obtained from South Africa and Argentina. And compared to existing records from
New England after they have been corrected for glacial isostatic adjustment (GIA) and steric influences.

This project will lead to an increased understanding of the driving mechanisms of sea-level change and could enhance predictions of 21st century sea-level rise and thus has important societal relevance. The project will support an early career PI and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Globally sea level is not uniform. The term global mean sea level is an averaged sea level elevation from all ocean basins over a 10 year satellite measurement period. At any given location the sea level could be different by meters. This necessitates the needs for sea level data at regional and even local scales. The satellite era (last 20 years) provides only a short glimpse at how sea level has changed over time. To understand how sea level has changed and why, longer sea-level records are required (longer than even the longest tide gauges ~150yrs). To develop these longer records (1000s years) microscopic marine organisms called foraminifera are used because they have and still organize themselves within the coastal zone by their tolerance to areal exposure during the tidal cycle. Whereby certain species occupy high elevations and can withstand long areal exposure whilst other require less exposure live at lower elevations relative to sea level. These are termed sea-level indicators. We use this technique to develop sea-level records for two areas in the South Atlantic Ocean where a near absence of millennial-scale sea-level data is much needed in order to understand what drives sea level change in different parts of the world.

We chose two study sites in each of Argentina and South Africa to develop new relative sea-level records and test the established foraminiferal-based method. In Argentina, we sampled at Bahia Blanca and Bahia San Blas. To our surprise only calcareous foraminifera occupied the salt marshes (generally temperate marshes are dominated by agglutinated foraminifera which adhere to the method described above). This enabled relative sea level for the past 4000 years to be reconstructed but with larger vertical uncertainties than anticipated (meters versus decimeters). Sea level reconstructions at Bahia San Blas show that sea level has been falling over this time period and agrees with previous reconstructions in the region. This was an improvement on the previous reconstructions which data points only indicate that sea level had to be above or below a given point (but never how far above or below).

To try and refine this record we tested the use of isotopes within the shells of the same calcareous foraminifera, a truly novel approach. Specifically we looked at Single and multi- proxy reconstructions were investigated based on foraminiferal δ13C and δ18O signatures and bulk sedimentary δ13C compositions with respect to modern marsh elevation. As calcareous foraminifera build their tests, they incorporate isotopic signatures of the ambient water at the time of calcification – a process that is referred to as biomineralization (Erez, 2003).  Therefore, the isotopic composition of calcareous foraminifera can be proxies for paleoceanographic conditions and potentially sea level. We found that the isotopic distribution of the species Ammonia parkinsoniana had a strong relationship with elevation across the salt marsh making it a good proxy for sea level and coupled to bulk sedimentary δ13C composition (Salt marsh sediments are composed of organic-rich material from vegetation or freshwater- or marine-derived organic matter sources. These varying sources of organic matter have distinctive δ13C signatures and can be used to identify where the sediment lies relative to sea level). Together, these data allowed the for four zones to be determined within the present salt marsh system relative to sea level (tidal flat, low marsh, mid-marsh, and high marsh). We then determined the fossil foraminifera and sediment isotopic compositions in order to infer how past sea level has changed. In the end we were able to refine the uncertainty in the record to less than one meter and show that sea level has been falling in coastal central Argentina since ~4000 years ago.
